Situation1: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I sit at my desk, blueprints spread before me, tracing lines that will become the new office’s heart. My phone buzzes with messages from the project manager—deadlines, revisions, expectations. Every inch of the floor plan must serve a purpose, every workspace must breathe efficiency. My mind races with calculations, but in the back of my head, a quiet voice reminds me it’s time for my daily puja. I glance at the small altar tucked in the corner of my office, the incense unlit, the bell untouched. I whisper a mantra under my breath, hoping it’s enough, but guilt gnaws at me. My family expects devotion, a full ritual, not this hurried whisper. I want to honor my faith, but the demands of my profession press in, relentless. My hands hover over the blueprints, torn between the world I build for others and the world I’m supposed to nurture within myself. The clock ticks, and I feel the weight of both roles, each pulling me in a different direction, neither willing to let go.
